Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of the earth's mantle plumbing system at the global scale using an advanced seismic imaging approach.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Improving the resolution of earth's mantle structure through seismic imaging is important for our understanding of the deep dynamic processes that are reflected in surface tectonics and ultimately give rise to earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. Seismic tomography utilizes seismic waves originating from natural earthquakes to illuminate the earth's interior using similar principles as used in medical imagery. While the long wavelength, smooth structure is now well documented, we strive to sharpen the picture and resolve smaller scale features that will help understand in detail how the internal circulation drives the motions of tectonic plates, and vice-versa, and obtain a better view of how heat is channeled from the deep interior to the surface, resulting not only in the system of volcanoes mid-ocean ridges but also in mid-plate volcanoes called "hotspots", such as the Hawaiian chain. Because hotter than average regions correspond to low seismic velocities, which are particularly difficult to image, their accurate imaging has not been possible until recently, with the advent of numerical methods to accurately compute the seismic wavefield propagation across the earth's mantle. This project builds upon our recent efforts to develop global seismic images of the entire mantle using such computations, and improve the sharpness of these images.

The main goal of this project is to finalize the construction of higher resolution (up to 200-400 km laterally) global 3D radially anisotropic shear velocity model of the whole mantle based on a time domain waveform inversion approach that has so far been applied only to the upper mantle, with promising results. This waveform inversion methodology builds upon 20 years of experience of the PI in waveform tomography using mode-based wavefield computations, as well as two generations of global upper mantle shear velocity models developed using long period fundamental mode and overtone waveforms (periods >60s) and numerical wavefield computations (Spectral Element Method). In order to resolve lower mantle structure, isolating wavepackets that contain body wave energy is necessary, therefore we propose to extend the period range of our dataset to 30s - this will also increase spatial resolution further in the upper mantle, while keeping computations manageable. Further goals of the proposal are to (1) obtain higher resolution in the lateral variations of radial anisotropy throughout the mantle, (2) test the sensitivity of the 30 s dataset to inversion for a global averaged S/P velocity conversion factor and (3) collect additional, shorter window (~30mn after origin time) waveforms down to 20s to include more P wave energy and perform additional iterations to obtain a global P velocity model of the lower mantle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global seismic waveform tomography aims at utilizing all the information contained in records of large distant earthquakes ("teleseisms"), combined across many earthquakes and many recordings around the global, to infer the three dimensional structure of the earth's mantle, with the goal of clarifying circulation of matter within the mantle, i.e. locate rising and sinking currents that ultimately drive plate tectonics at the earth's surface. To achieve this, one needs to be able to predict the seismic wavefield that results from the propagation of seismic waves through a model of the heterogeneous earth. Comparison with the observations leads to differences that can then be exploited to improve the model and bring it closer to the real earth, in a process called "inversion".

In the last 15 years, numerical methods as well as the power of computers have made it possible to accurately compute the teleseismic wavefield without making approximations on the strength or smoothness of the heterogeneity traversed. These methodologies have been progressively implemented and led to the first higher resolution mantle models, using waveform data filtered at relatively long periods (~30s). Yet, to further improve the sharpness of the tomographic images, it is necessary to increase the frequency range of the computations, which is computationally very expensive, since the cost of one wavefield computation increases roughly as the cube of the highest frequency, and many earthquake sources, as well as several iterations are needed to reach convergence of the model. Even though computer power has been steadily increasing, it is useful to investigate ways in which the computations can be made more efficient.Two such avenues have been explored during the period of this grant.

The first approach consists in the development and testing of a methodology that relies on the concept of "stacked sources". Instead of performing one wavefield computation per earthquake source, resulting in hundreds of computations for one iteration of the tomographic inversion, this consists in aligning all the sources in time and computing a single wavefield computation for the sum of the sources. Such a methodology was first proposed ten years ago but was not further pursued, because of the concern that in the process of stacking, some information is irremediably lost. We are showing that this is actually not the case, and that the information can be recovered by computing cross-correlations between the summed traces at pairs of stations. An advantage of working with the cross-correlations is that the large amplitude surface waves, which dominate the summed traces, can be isolated and weighted down, allowing the information from lower amplitude seismic waves that sample the deeper mantle to be accessible. We have developed the methodology and performed a series of synthetic tests to demonstrate the validity of our approach and are presently applying it to real data, first to demonstrate that we can reach the same level of resolution at the global scale as with a conventional approach. Another application of this approach is that it opens the possibility of conducting numerous synthetic tests that are inaccessible using conventional computations, such as for example testing the advantage of one inversion algorithm versus another, or exploring the trade-offs between different physical parameters.

The second approach consists in isolating a target region of the earth where higher resolution is sought - for example the root of a deep mantle plume -  and using the concept of time-reversal mirrors to separate the wavefield computation into three parts: (1) from the earthquake source to the borders of the target region; (2) inside the target region; (3) from the target region to the recording stations. Computation of the wavefield is then performed only once in regions (1) and (3), while iterations of the inversion are performed only within the target region (2), saving considerable computing time, and making it possible to attain sufficiently high frequencies to investigate such questions as the presence and morphology of extreme structures, called "ultra low velocity zones" inside the plume root. During the period of this grant, we have developed the methodology, and applied it to the case when recording stations are within the target region (i.e. situation (1)+(2)). We have started implementing the third leg of the procedure.
